text: Hoping you have no notifications and I'm not waking you up in the middle of the night with this, It's likely my downtime happens in the morning more than at any point in the day haha.
That sounds interesting, you have a similar story to a few of my friends.

Before i say anything about my story and things, I'll tell you that motion graphics artists tend to do really well in comp. Most compositors have little to no knowledge in many of the skills that motion graphics give you, more specifically design and animation; If you play those strenghts I'm sure you'll get to where you want :slightly_smiling_face:

The first hurdle of course, is to make the leap from roto to comp, which is always quite hard. I'll be glad to give you any usual feedback on your reel, if you want to show me work in progress stuff it's also good.

My story is not too interesting; I studied Multimedia engineering because it was the closest thing to videogames I could find back in Colombia. It was a new program and a total fiasco; what was supposed to be a career that balanced arts and engineering turned into a war between the teachers for what was more useful in life. The engineers won the war and slowly displaced any semblance of art education out. We got caught on that silly conflict and it really hurt us; I was part of the second promotion, by the end of the career i couldn't draw and couldn't program either. What I could do, was to Maya like a champ (for Colombian standards) thanks to 3 years of maya worshop classes that somehow managed to go unscathed in their little turf war.

I also learned some good deal of After Effects on the way, mostly preparing for a motion graphics class. It was sad as the teacher was not very good and I already knew the software better than him since the first class.
In all that, I got a reputation for being good at maya
and some guys from the first promotion were working on a small postproduction company (which was the second largest in Colombia) working for advertising
one of them recommended me for a small freelance job, the vfx supe and head of prod loved me and did all they could to retain me.
there I met an English friend who was backpacking in Colombia and decided to stay there for a while. He worked at framestore commercials as a Flame artist donkeys years ago.

At that point I was working mostly as a 3d generalist; mostly doing pack shots. My English friend was always showing me his weird comp tricks; he was super good at doing set extensions and projections.
And I fell in love with comp looking at his work. In a weird chance, One of the Flame artists left and I asked the company's manager if she would let me try my hand at it.
She said she'd rather have me do it than finding someone new, so I started my career as a comper
Basically reading the flame manual back to back haha.
From then, I basically changed jobs every year
and had a few really good mentors that taught me a lot about comp and vfx supping.
In the end, I was working in flame and had my own clients, went on freelancing to improve my life/work balance (it actually works once you have enough clients).
Worked as a freelancer with a particular team I fell in love with; they were starting a company and enticed me in

We managed to do some really cool things, far above Colombian standards; and at that point my reel was looking better than your average Colombian compositor of the time. Then, my english friend came and told me that Framestore was working on 47 ronin and gravity and were quite keen on finding more compositors, and it would be a sweet spot for people to get visas from outside.
I sent my reel, got interviewed, and withing a month i was abandoning my company to come here.
I can show you the reel i made when i got here.
I still think that there's a balance of showing that i could use nuke, and them being desperate hahaha.
<https://vimeo.com/8018819> the password is: reel

It is my observation, than more than recommendations, it's important to have inside information on those sweet spots, when companies really need people; which happens every once in a while to all of them, as they grow and shrink depending on the demand they get from projects, the unexpected and the way the crunch times of different companies meet.
I've seen plenty of my friends getting their jobs a similar way.

My girlfriend also changed careers in her late 20s from contemporary art to comp. Her escape from prep happened while she was working at Lipsync, thanks to a comp supervisor that was left to to a project all by himself with her as his prep assistance. He starting throwing comp tasks at her and as she was ready and did well, in no time, she was doing comp full time...

So maybe another observation is that many times, climbing the ladder happens when you're standing in the right place to help doing harder things, once you prove yourself, you pretty much stay there; that of course is more likely to happen in smaller or more chaotic companies where those situations happen more often.
Hope this was not too rambly, It's a hard question; the story thing. I also hope this is of use, and I would like to hear about your motivations for heading into this field and stuff.
